reviews.content: Four strangers, a family of three, and a couple come to an unconventional wellness center run by a Russian immigrant (Nicole Kidman). She asks them to surrender their phones and be open-minded to a variety of therapies, and as the series plays out, we find out they're dealing with a number of issues, including death, substance abuse, bad relationships, anger, and crippling self-doubt. Kidman's character herself has been traumatized and is on a journey of her own, but as a therapist some of the techniques she employs teeter on the edge of being unethical and possibly harmful to her clients, so that even as they make progress, it's a conflicting, somewhat scary ride.At the heart of it for me, or at least what I thought was most successful, was the storyline revolving around the parents and their daughter who were trying to come to terms with the suicide of their son/brother. The feelings as they unraveled were truly touching, and the performances from Asher Keddie and Michael Shannon were excellent. Also wonderful were Melissa McCarthy and Bobby Cannavale who play an author and retired NFL athlete who start off detesting one another. It's a little predictable where their story is going, but it has nuance, humor, and a depth of feeling that kept it from becoming sappy.Less successful was the subplot with the married couple who've lost their sizzle (Samara Weaving and Melvin Gregg). Her self-esteem issues were the most well developed and held some interest, but it just didn't seem like enough was done with this pair. The guests are rounded out with a mother whose husband left her for a younger woman (Regina Hall), and an uncover reporter (Luke Evans). Hall's performance stands out for its intensity, and how her story intersects the therapist's adds a nice little wrinkle.Overall, it's a well-made production, with great cinematography, trippy effects, and nice soundtrack. The ending is overly rosy, but there was so much pain in the lives of these characters that I forgive the series (or the author) for that. It definitely held my interest and was fun to binge watch.

This series starts with such a bang and is promising and highly mysterious once the characters unfold, but from there on it's just a drag of the characters, the story goes in to lose its pace and strength. The worst is the ending where as if the writer was not sure which way to go but chose something that all will find appeasing. I don't know what genre to put this in as well. It's starts as a drama then starts to look like a drama thriller and then falls flat on its face. Bad script as well Sorry to all who have given high ratings, but I was totally disappointed and found it a waste of my time.

This adaptation of the enigmatic novel by Liane Moriarty is supremely watchable but flawed. Buoyed by some tremendous core performances but the plot wobbles often as the show leans far too heavily on the star power, sucking time away from Regina Hall's mesmerically volatile Carmel and making Ben & Jess seem hilariously superfluous in comparison to McCarthy, Kidman or Shannon. It's got some nice photography and it'll keep you guessing along the journey - but it doesn't particularly stick the landing.

reviews.review_title: Good story for those who have the patience to let it develop.
reviews.content: If you liked Big Little Lies and were waiting for something similar let me tell you this show has the perfect ingredients.Based on a book by the same author, check.David E. Kelly behind the project, check.Nicole Kidman as the lead, check.What else do you need. Just put your trust in these talented people, sit back and wait to be entertained.
There were at least a dozen life lessons taught through the existence and experiences of every character. In my eyes, that makes this series meaningful and gloriously made.

reviews.review_title: I don't get the bad reviews
reviews.content: It's not a perfect show, but from the first 3 episodes that have been released it's intriguing- there's an overall uneasy feeling, the acting is very good for the most part (the scenes between Melissa Mcarthy and Bobby Cannavale's characters steal the show) and the scenery is beautiful!! I definitely will be watching the other episodes as they are released.

Nine Perfect Strangers had a great cast and a nice prompt for a story. However, and even though right from the start you know that something is wrong with the whole establishment, as the story progressed, the series got weaker and weaker, with a lukewarm built up and a disappointing ending.

Inappropriate boundaries in therapy should not be glorified. I hate the way this show ended - everyone accepting multiple boundary transgressions and believing that the ends justified the means. A therapist who does not let a patient lead, who pushes them out of comfort again and again, who puts them at risk for their own selfish needs is an abusive therapist. This would NOT heal people. It would traumatise them. Their loyalty to Masha was trauma bonding, not transcendence. We should not glorify cult leader tactics, they exist in the real world and have done great harm.

The beginning of the plot was so interesting and mysterious, thought some really crazy twist would happen but the reality was that the ending was so flat and corny that made it really boring, it wasn't mysterious at all. The series was very repetitive and not much happened that was worth the while.

What a wonderfully twisted and intriguing show. Nicole Kidman is frightful and yet delightful. Nine Perfect Strangers has me on the edge of my seat. Nine Perfect Strangers is a pot of hot water on the stove threatening to boil over.Well done, Hulu.

"You have all come here to die. I will bring you back."Nine stressed city dwellers visit a boutique health-and-wellness resort that promises healing and transformation. The resort's director is a woman on a mission to reinvigorate their tired minds and bodies. Nine Perfect Strangers is another limited series by David E. Kelley, creator of Big Little Lies and Sharp Objects, based on the novel by Liane Moriarty, who also wrote the novel Big Little Lies. We're greeted with what we've seen before: big cast, impressive cinematography, and an intriguing mystery. The story may not be as fleshed out as the other shows, but the show is interesting enough to go all the way through. The cast is really what carries it. As strange as the casting may be, especially Nicole Kidman, they all end up fulfilling their characters. We reach into a different level of each character every episode. It can take a while to find a liking to all characters but by the last couple episodes we can gage who they are and how much we like them. Melissa McCarthy, Michael Shannon, Bobby Cannavale, and Tiffany Boone stood out from the whole ensemble. You can see definite growth. But the real star is Regina Hall as Carmel. From the start, she's the character we can sympathize the most with, but she has so much to give and she gives it her all!Continuing on with characters, part of the problem with the show is the characters. There's nine plus people we need to get through in a short period of time, and as you might have been able to tell, not all get the treatment needed. I feel bad for Samara Weaving and Melvin Gregg because they were so forgettable, maybe not Weaving as much. Their story is essentially thrown away by the end and they didn't do much for the story. The family that gets most of the time has an interesting arc, but it can be a little too much time when they come to a conclusion and then go back to it an episode later. Nicole Kidman's story ends up crossing paths with another and it's handle in a way that's so unsatisfying. Jonathan Levine could've raised the stakes with the way he directed it, but as a new genre for him I think he wanted to focus on other aspects. The first two episodes were very impressive and the ending didn't really nail it, but the others I liked. Episode 6 actually took my interest in how it was shown visually and written. The cinematography looks absolutely stunning, especially outside with the nature shots. You can see the inspiration taken from Midsommar. The overall aesthetic was great, and I think that's what they wanted to get at. I just wish they fleshed out the story much more. In the end, Nine Perfect Strangers is an entertaining watch, but nothing super captivating. Each episode has something interesting, but it doesn't quite lace everything together nicely.

I can't tell you how glad I was when I was finally through with this mini-series. I only watched the last episode in fast-forward because otherwise I would probably have fallen asleep. Even for a feature film of normal length, the story about a Russian therapist who is primarily concerned with herself would have been too poor and too quickly transparent. Here you are tortured for 8 episodes, at a pace as if you were riding a tricycle along an interstate. Nicole Kidman in the lead role has the necessary skills, but her Masha is ultimately just a cliché about Russian women - here, unfortunately, with too much Botox - and of the rest of the cast, only Melissa McCarthy can keep me from falling asleep to some extent. A series that completely wastes its potential.

No spoilers just commentary.A very intriguing tale of lives. The most important thing to me is there isn't one bit of filler in this series, every minute and moment adds something interesting. Each character has their story, their secrets and their vices. As the show progresses and unfolds, the more info is divulged and unraveled, a surreal turn of events makes itself known.The cinematography and visuals are glorious, views are breathtaking. The contrast of the setting to the unraveling characters.The fruit smoothies look delicious.The Russian host (Nicole Kidman) has no need to be Russian, it adds nothing to the plot, and doesn't sound Russian, I am not sure why there needs to be an exotic host from somewhere that isn't the US.. it ends up sounding like a faux, generic European accent and it is annoying. She is very interesting without it, is the perfect ring leader of the ragtag group.It's hard to not be absorbed in this fascinating, riveting, and captivating series.Update. My initial review was about half way through the series. After watching the end it's definitely slower as far as pacing goes. Also Nicole Kidman is incredibly hard to watch in this just as she usually is in everything. The bad accent makes it worse.The momentum just falls off a bit, maybe could have been shortened by an episode? It's worth the watch but it's not groundbreaking by any means.

reviews.review_title: Aussie Kidman attempts a Russian Accent, Why?
reviews.content: The Russian accent is one of the most difficult to master as all spoken English words will have a harsh sound to them. Nicole gets this right maybe one word in 50. My thoughts are why would they add that detail? Surely anyone can see that it's just terrible, so many options and making her a Russian adds little to the story.That being said not much happens in this resort retreat series. There is no drama, well maybe you could call a potato sack race tense. After 3 episodes there is nothing there, every show ends with a cliffhanger sentence to lure us to watch another episode.Even the title is misleading, as 3 of the 9 are family members. This is just bizarre that this got approved. 2 stars for the Australian scenery.

I expected a thriller or mystery but the story did not end up going anywhere near where I thought it was going. Every character, except maybe Nicole Kidman, was amazing in this show. As the characters progressed, I felt myself liking each of them far more than I initially thought I would. The scenery is eerie and beautiful setting the landscape that things are not what they seem in this paradise-esqe, "tranquil" place. The show unfolded giving you just enough to remain vested, but I never really could figure out where it was going. Even one episode before the show ended I was still not sure which direction the show was heading. It seemed like the mystery of what was really going on was intentional and I appreciated that. Then when the show finally starts to come full circle, utter disappointment settled in because the ending was unfortunately significantly anticlimactic. Which was such a huge let down because it had all the tools to be great, except the most important part: the story. The ending could be considered " happy" and was intended to be satisfying, but if I'm honest, I was very annoyed. I can't say I regretted watching the show, it just could have been so much stronger and many elements that seemed like there were going to be of some significance to the overall story, fell completely flat. I can't say the show was terrible, but it wasn't all that good either.
On episode 3, but bored out of my mind. Trying to stick with it. But why?

reviews.review_title: Never read the book, went in blind
reviews.content:
Another reviewer stated those giving high scores must be fans of the book. I'm not, never read it or thankfully non of the reviews on here prior to taking the plunge.See, as I'm usually the sort to despise pretentious garbage and the usual crowd of "intellects" that sing its praises to the rest of us lowly peasants; I tend to give more credence to honest reviews (most of which these days seem low).Most 9 or 10 star reviews on IMDB are from cast/crew of the films or their families/friends.On this occassion however, I'm genuinely surprised at the negativity for this show.This isn't a show I would usually go for but there was nothing else on and so I went for it. I'm five episodes in and find that despite it being a slow burning mystery and tale of intrigue, it actually does have a decent pace and isn't filled with long moments of artsy staring into the camera, deafening silences or angled shots of inanimate objects.Another reviewer stated Melissa Mcarthy is the only decent act in this show....?Erm, what? Whilst she definitely is great in this, they're all decent performances. Michael Shannon's is fantastic.Others saying Nicole Kidman's character is "strange", "weird", "like an alien" etc......
I'm sorry for this but you're showing your IQ levels up a bit here; as she's MEANT to be like that....that's the POINT!Her accent? Meh......but I'm not gonna get hung up about it. She's not the first to mess up an accent, nor will she be the last. If you're the sort to let one little thing ruin everything for you, then good luck with that I guess.Overall I laughed out loud a few times and got a lump in my throat on others.I may be getting more soppy over my years but I find the gradual bond between the characters to be heart warming too.All the while the plot thickens and the boiling pot simmers in the background.I'm enjoying it a lot and I'm usually a tough-to-please member of the audience......Each to their own though......

reviews.review_title: Michael Shannon has some incredible range.
reviews.content: Ok, obviously I haven't finished the series so there are no spoilers here.But this show is the one that really sealed in Michael Shannon's incredible range for me. It's astounding how much different he can be from his bad guy persona or his mafia/crime boss characters. Honestly, he makes the whole show for me. I can't believe it's the same guy.I'm sure the other actors are absolutely killing it. I think Melissa McCartney is also showing some range but Michael Shannon just dominates the screen for me.Worth watching.

Firstly, I think you need to watch the entire season to get what the series is on about, and if you don't like it then, that's alright, but judging this show based off the first couple episodes is nugatory because the the whole season is about what's gonna happen at the end. So don't watch it if you're unwilling to go the distance, which isn't that far, just 8 episodes.At first, I thought it was going to have a "White lotus" type of ending, just some cliche finale where murder happened and the culprit is revealed, but not in a million years would I have guessed the direction the show was going even though there were several inklings along the way. I don't think it's the best show out there or anything, but it definitely doesn't deserve poor ratings; the first couple episodes weren't bad either, just left you a little all over the place because you don't get to piece together the full story yet, only that something unorthodox is happening so it's definitely worth a wait till the end before making up your mind about it. And if you are prudent when watching each character's story, there could be a thing or two you can learn from it as well.

I love this whacky bizarre story and the crew is masterful at what they do. The unloved song is one of the best choices ever! The cast is perfect I enjoy them in nearly anything especially Samara Weaving, Mellisa McCarthy, Bobby Cannavele and Micheal Shannon are all awesome! I kinda understand the hate Nine Perfect Strangers may have gotten but it truly is magnificent, captivating and thrilling.
Fantastic cast totally torpedoed by terrible pacing and direction. The longer it goes on, the less interested I am in the characters' outcomes.

reviews.review_title: Great acting but very average show
reviews.content: First and foremost I have read the book and did not really like it. It seemed a bit pointless and the twist it boasted having was nonexistent. However when I saw the casting for the show I decided to give it a go. The casting is quite different to what I'd imagine the characters to look like from the book, however I still thought the casting was great. Especially Melissa McCarthy, Bobby Canavale, and Regina Hall. Their characters were hilarious. I like that they made it quite funny; they mixed the drama with comedy wonderfully. They have changed quite a few things from the book, especially with Carmel's character. I preferred the book's plot which saw Masha having a heart attack from overworking rather than being shot. They changed the end with them being locked in the room...that scene should have been a lot longer, and the Marconi's were supposed to be in there. It's quite an important scene in the book and they're supposed to work together and figure out how to escape, there's so much more to that scene; it's so much more detailed in the novel and they made it almost insignificant in the show. Overall I think the acting was great but they had a chance to improve the book and they failed.

reviews.review_title: A show about trauma, and about people that have it, never more timely
reviews.content: It can be funny and disturbing. Despite the warnings about possibly triggering, it wasn't that bad for me (being diagnosed with PTSD). There's a lot of intense psychology, so maybe not for people who aren't into that kind of thing. It is also a mystery / thriller, as there seems to be an alternate story still waiting to be uncovered, especially with Kidman's character (who is a great character). It also probably won't sit well with religious types, given some of the themes.Much like the therapy endured by the guests, the show starts softer and lighter, them becomes more intense each episode. Sometimes it almost hints at mystical elements, but this is not a primary theme, merely a plot device. This show is rooted in science and psychology, not the supernatural. The most incredible thing it does is flesh out the characters; we start off thinking they are all deeply flawed, then come to understand their viewpoints. It's a sort of exercise in empathy, which is great for the times. I would definitely say it's worth the watch, if even just for the wonderful Melissa McCarthy.

reviews.review_title: I've Read The Book, So I Know...
reviews.content: If you haven't read the book, you shouldn't be leaving a review yet.I get that you may be having a hard time getting past Kidman. Same. But she is one small part in a very large picture and as much as she annoys you, it'll make sense (you'll still hate her, but it'll make sense) in the end.So refrain from leaving a review until you've finished the series. I promise it's nothing like you think. It's worth the wait and all the slow, seemingly pointless information will all make sense. You all live in a world of instant gratification and forget what suspense is like, even when it's not causing your blood pressure to increase.The TV adaptation follows the novel very closely. If you read the book you'll enjoy it on the screen. If you haven't read the book, sit back, shut up, and get ready for a bumpy ride. THEN leave your review.

Slow. Uneventful. Hugely disappointing. Plus Regina Hall sucks in this movie. Someone needed to acknowledge that. I only stayed with it because I was waiting for the "thriller" or "mystery" to start. It never does. This is a drama. Mostly about dealing with death. And a dull one.

... or perhaps any other show involving interactions between strangers. To summarize this one, 9 people (whom are not all strangers) gather at a spa, where they are sent on acid trips by the proprietor, resulting in lots of screaming, stupidity, and visitations from dead people, all in an effort for the proprietor to hallucinate her own dead daughter permanently. You'll want to punch each of the characters in the face, hard, at some point.I do appreciate the effort to provide entertainment, but this one was a drudgery to get through.

I have not read the book because I'm not a fan of the author but the premise sounded interesting. I love Luke Evans (Lars), he is such an underrated actor and he led me to watching 9 Perfect Strangers. After seeing the trailer I thought maybe the story would take a dark turn so I went on Goodreads for spoilers on the book.First let me say Nicole Kidman (Masha) has gotten more beautiful with age. I recently watched Malice and while she was cute she is definitely better now. Also I think she did a great job with the Russian accent.Michael Shannon was absolutely heartbreaking as Napoleon and he had me crying a few times. Every time Samara Weaving (Jessica) spoke I kept thinking of her character in the fourth season of the show No Activity. She was really good and so was the guy who played her husband.I just binge watched Black Monday starring Regina Hall as a badass Wall Street stockbroker in the eighties. After watching that then seeing her as Carmel I was struck by what an amazing actress she is. At one point she completely terrified me.My only complaint is the relationship between Frances (Melissa McCarthy) and Tony (Bobby Cannavale) as there was no chemistry whatsoever and the relationship felt forced.I doubt I would ever read the book but I did enjoy the series.

reviews.review_title: Abusive therapist cures deeply troubled patients?
reviews.content: There are so many things wrong with this show. I was hoping that the end would show the people who attended the retreat were wrong to trust Masha and that they'd be (rightly) traumatized from their experiences. But somehow their lives became perfect, complete with fairytale endings. Not only did Masha cross boundaries with the retreat goers, but she also had zero qualifications to be doing any sort of therapy, as far as the viewer knows. I was waiting for a character to ask for her credentials and push for it, but it never happened. To me, Masha came off as extremely sketchy, untrustworthy, and cult leader-ish, even and especially up until the end. It was sad that all of the retreat goers stopped questioning her insane tactics after a while. In reality, I do not believe any of these people would be cured by the extreme "therapeutic" methods, but would instead need to be healed all over again from the experiences they just had. Masha was painted in a far too sympathetic light. While the acting was great and somewhat moving at times, overall this show is promoting harmful ideas. That ruined it for me.

The storyline quite lure me to watch but when things go halfway, just quite hard to get focus once the dose is the reason for the consequences. It just makes the rest of story go lame as anything could happen. But the set up is good as strangers come together but the spark between them just boring n the root cause just too hard to convince.

reviews.review_title: This is a terrible show - contrived, phony and potentially dangerous
reviews.content: The first few episodes were fantastic - great character writing, nuanced performances, nicely directed and edited. Loved it, couldn't wait for more. By the end, a few things became apparent. Masha really only focuses on three people - the family, and the result ends up encouraging unfaciliated psilocybin trips, something I vehemently disagree with and could be extremely dangerous (note, I am not at all against psilocybin as a therapeutic tool, just its misguided use). The young couple are ignored and don't have any therapy at all. Nor does Lars. The other couple help each other. By the end, the whole thing is hopelessly contrived, ignorant and phony, and I despised the last five minutes. All those hints at anything sinister or foreboding (which pretty much drives the whole show) are a complete red-herring.

So mad at myself for watching the whole 1st season. I mean, I knew it was probably horrible a few episodes back, but I kept thinking the promise of the 1st episode would pan out. It didn't.Nicole Kidman's worst role, ever. Terrible fake Russian accent and just one dimensional. I usually like her, but in this role she couldn't take the leap. Mealy mouthed controlling guru person. Ewwwww.Way too, too much time spent on the grieving family. Episode after episode, same ol' stuff. None of that was ever resolved. Just bor-ring. The interesting InstaGirl and her husband could have been used more and had a good story line. Like do therapy on a social media addict!Ironic that Kidman would act in such a blatant condemnation of "Western psychology" after being married to Tom Cruise, who lectures about his Scientology beliefs that all psychiatry is bad. I just am shocked. Not to mention, it's incredibly irresponsible to even suggest that dosing people with mushrooms, LSD, Ecstasy, etc is even a good or therapeutic idea. I'm a psychonaut from the 60s, and still use mushrooms, but you have to take care, esp with LSD, etc. And what she did to them, leaving them, taking it herself, and all for a self-serving reason, is nothing a show should give an unclear message about. Esp a show dealing with suicide (not one, but TWO). Not to mention the way Carmel was treated. I realize that psychiatry is imperfect, but for the mentally ill (esp violent), you need something besides hallucinogens and vague, New Age mantras and silliness. I agree that psychedelics should be allowed to be researched and the laws relaxed, and they can help, in certain circumstances (NOT the truly mentally ill) to facilitate therapy, but this show was just WAY, way out there, and never did come down to Earth. Like a bunch of dumb 14yr olds making a show. In responsible hands (NOT Masha's), they can do good, but this is not it and just adds to the stigma it is seemingly trying to end.I don't know how to take this show. Is it a parody of amateur New Age gurus? Or is it being serious (with the lukewarm "twist" at the end)? Plea for greater acceptance of psychedelics? Or kind of horror? Or just trying to be edgy? I can't get a read on it at all and it's frustrating. I'm going to go take huge doses of magic mushrooms, LSD, Ecstasy, and DMT and think about it as I experience ego death with my guru... Seriously, I lost a sibling to suicide last Christmas, my best friend, and a parent to it some years ago, so it is just bizarre and troubling, suicide being the main thread through the episodes. How NOT to accept death that is already, by virtue of suicide, incredibly hard to grieve and accept. Obviously none of the series creators or writers have ever dealt with it themselves and if they have, then shame on them.

Intrigue, humour, drama.... It's like a discovery voyage into the lives of the 9 strangers and the staff. Layers being peeled each time. 3 episodes deep and there's still so many questions. It's going suck now having an episode a week. I might wait till week 7 then watch the remaining 6 episodes at once!

This show starts out OK and keeps you intrigued.....to read the reviews along the way to be informed that everything will all make sense at the end goes a little further in keeping you confident that everything will come together with an explanation by the last episode....to then get to the final episode, I am more lost than I was at the beginning. This show makes stuff all sense and I have no idea wtf it meant after watch the entire series without disruption.

reviews.review_title: Love the series. Hate Nicole's fake Russian accent.
reviews.content:
Love the story line and the acting.But why, oh why is the brilliant David Kelley making us suffer through every episode by forcing us to listen to Nicole's irritating fake Russian accent?My rating is:
10 minus 2 (for Nicole's horrific fake Russian accent) = 8.

The performances in this are great, I don't fault any of the actors, they were wonderful. Unfortunately, this is a boring and meandering story that ultimately leads to a rather ordinary and simplified conclusion. Not the greatest but not terrible. Too long and somewhat dull. Watch it for the performances if you'd like.

There is some great casting here but underutilized. The series was very slow and the suspense was meh! The repeated smoothie making process was annoying after sometime. However, the truth of what happens in most of these wellness centers is well shown. Not looking forward to another season.

reviews.review_title: Not my usual cup of tea, but so well done that I'm hooked
reviews.content: Usually I'm a pretty harsh critic. Usually I don't care for tearjerker dramas (refuse to watch This is Us and its doppelgangers on other networks). This show is so well done in every aspect though that through episode 4 I'm hooked. Intro music and graphics awesome. Writing awesome. Story pacing excellent. Characters well done. Acting spectacular. Music selection appropriately cheeky. I keep breaking into tears... not normal for me. Adds laughs here and there. Drama seems realistic, not manufactured.

"Nine Perfect Strangers" (single season, 8 eps, 45-55 mins, Hulu) is a pretty fun/decent ride since its production is top tier: all star cast and A-team writers and director. The visuals are splendid from actresses such as Samara Weaving and Nicole Kidman, the resort/spa/retreat environment, and the psychedelics that occur. The story itself centers on the spa guests' faults, regrets, transgressions, insecurities, etc, and the pace is pretty fast since we have to examine those elements for each of the nine in addition to several of the troubled staff loyal to Nicole's "Masha" character. I believe this was designed as a single-season mini-series so you're going to wish there was time/budget for a 13-ep run instead of the short-ish 8 eps. Especially since the final scene makes no sense, apparently was thrown together at the last minute, too bad, and those two things are why it's a 7 instead of an 8 or 9 for me.

This is a series that grows on you with each episode. The cast may get you to episode one, the characters and performances may get you to episode 2, but, by episode 3 you will probably be hooked. I give this limited series a 7.9 (good) out of 10. {Drama}

I got to two and a half episodes and was bored out of my mind. Others have said its slow to develop. Maybe I'll give it another chance one day when I have nothing else to binge...but I just couldn't get any farther. Most of the characters were kind of awful, particularly Carmel and Tony. Jessica is pretty bad but she's supposed to be. Anyway, none of the them were likable to me so I didn't really care much about their plight and why they're here in the first place. Then we have Kidman's accent and her overall "non answers" testing the patience of everyone around her. Not entertaining for me, just frustrating to listen to.

reviews.review_title: Waste of their talent and your time
reviews.content: In Episode 2, there's a scene where the 9 participants dig their own graves. Each boring, whiny, exhausting character* should have jumped in and covered themselves with dirt, saving viewers from this dull, pretentious and soul-sucking effort. (* Melissa McCarthy & Bobby Cannavale,the two only interesting strangers in the whole lot, can stay above ground.)

Episode 2, I could feel my life draining away along with the premise and the script . . . Was there a script?It was midway through the swimming pool scene when I felt ANY desire to witness even one more second of this . . . Tripe . . . Evaporate. Gone.I realized this is, in fact, awful.As another reviewer pointed out, it is nearly impossible to not compare this with 'The White Lotus' which just ended. But, really . . . No . . . All these two have in common is people going to a resort. 'The White Lotus' is fabulous, on every level. This is nothing. Absolutely nothing.And Nichol . . . Wow . . . She's awful. Her hair, on the other hand is an entity in and of itself. But just as lacking in credibility.

reviews.review_title: A Unique take on a wellness retreat Superb
reviews.content: Wasn't sure what to expect from the title but was very pleasantly surprised by the unique storyline of Nicole Kidman being the owner of a wellness health retreat she delivers a super performance and the cast is stunning the story is well written and scripted to allow comedic intervals within that are perfect for the exceptionally talented Mellisa McCarthy. I am really enjoying this show and hope it is commissioned for a few seasons.

This mini-series is one that needs to take the time to develop. I think a lot of the bad reviews we're written after only seeing 2 or 3 episodes. And, if you expect a good horror or thriller: this isn't for you.But when you go on the trip of nine perfect strangers you're gonna fall in love with the wonderful acting and heartfelt (and -broken) story lines. Kidman, McCarty, Cannavale, Evans, Shannon, Keddy, Hall, And others deliver authentic and beautiful performances. McCarty stands out because of this genre: it think she hasn't been funnier before and yet so lovable and real. Kidman adapts a thick accent, one could argue about it, but one could also see that she is again giving a wonderful character with emotional depth.A smart choice of the series was the way suspension was build. Not only does the viewer want to know what is keeping the characters stuck in pain, who shot Masha (Kidman), who is sending the threats, but also the series takes you to a point where you wonder if this kind of therapy is more damaging then healing and might even demand innocent victims. And who could imagine that at the end you would root for one of the more debatable characters. That's good storytelling to me. Love, love, loved it.

This show is amazing I honestly could NOT stop watching, Great casting very Thrilling and suspenseful it definitely had me hooked. Going into this show I honestly did not expect much but boy was I wrong, I'm not gonna spoil anything but trust me you should definitely give this show a watch it will not let you down. 100000 out of 10 perfection, thanks Hulu.

Kidman is dreadful! I don't know why I bothered. I couldn't watch Big Little Lies because it was superficial people doing "competitive parenting" and Kidman being blank-faced. This brings terrible acting, woeful accents, rich people navel gazing and Kidman being blank-faced. I kept watching solely for Frances and Tony. The rest are meh...
It was filmed in Australia. Why pretend it's California? So many things wrong.

Review By Kamal KI watch this series for its visual beauty ( the tranquillium wellness centre looks amazing , sounds soothing I would like to check in given a choice). Yes , it's only an eyes candy series with a bunch of good looking people in nice clothes lounging in a beautiful ranch and pools . And sometimes they reacts to the psychedelic dosesMore importantly, if you watch carefully it complies to the modern concept of inclusiveness- the casts have been chosen carefully via algorithmic model which ensured the compliance to all dimensions of diversity - ethnicities , LGBTQ , body types and skin tones.It's very basic and modern mainstream series which probably wanted to repeat the "big little lies" success-this time with Melissa McCarthy and Nicole Kidman combination.

reviews.review_title: Weak original novel and tedious mini series
reviews.content: This is the weakest of Liane Moriarty's novels. Very disappointed that this is the one green lit for production when several of the others would have made much more interesting TV. Try "What Alice Forgot" next time.The series follows the same boring characters in the book, in a highly unlikely retreat set up and in the first three episodes, it's plot development is just as tedious as the book.I'm just hoping the screenplay writers tear up the rest of the book and come up with something halfway believable.
Haven't read the book.I feel unpleasant when while watching Kidman. Not sure if I should hate or feel sorry for her.Intriguing beginning, very weak ending.

reviews.review_title: Mediocrity is the best description for the show.
reviews.content: The only great aspect of the show is the cast. The rest is so mediocre. Script and dialogues are really poor. I believe if you are making a show about microdosing as a core of the show, then you have to have some knowledge about this topic because it seems like writers read only Drugs for For Dummies. The whole show seems really fake to me from Nicole Kidman weirdly acting Russian woman(looool) to the general idea of taking magic smoothies. Not good at all.

reviews.review_title: A pitch perfect, post California Dreamin' psychodramatic take on 'Ten Little Indians'.
reviews.content: Nine Perfect Strangers is an extraordinarily captivating show.It reimagines 'Ten Little Indians' as a post modern fable of the present day. The casting is incredible and everyone puts in tremendous performances. It may also be the first time that Melissa McCarthy is actually acting consciously and dramatically and not just playing some typecast version of herself.Cannavale and Shannon are in top form as well.I cannot recommend this enough. Can't wait for the next episode!

reviews.review_title: Francis and Tony were the only good thing
reviews.content: This show was kind of pointless. I thought it would be a thriller but it wasn't. It was weird. There were some funny moments between Francis and Tony, if the whole show was about them I would have been happy. Apart from that I honestly don't understand the hype. Nicole Kidman's Russian accent was absolutely terrible.

reviews.review_title: A very Blah sort of experience
reviews.content: If you believe in the sort of spirituality that is thrown about in this show it may appeal to you, after 3 episodes the show hasnt really given the viewer much else other then spirituality discussions.The acting is very good, otherwise this would have been a much lower rating. If you are looking for another Big Little Lies or the Undoing this is far from it, no thrills, no real suspense, very disappointing.Some reviewers are saying this is the same as the book it's based on, if that is the case the book must have been a very slow slow read.Would be shocked if anyone really believes the pay off at the end is worth it.

I wish they would have released all the episodes show all at once. This is a show that gets better with each episode. I really loved episode 3. The show is very well done, at least the first three episodes. From writing to editing and score and cinematography and acting. Especially the acting. Again it is a show that gets better with each episode and while I liked first episode, it was the second episode that really surprised me and the third episode made me love the show already. The characters become more complex after each episode and the themes and story are executed in a good and creative way. Honestly everything is well done. I probably will do a better review after they release all the episodes, but I am glad I checked this out.

I binged the whole series but the last episode left me disappointed. So, first, the good. This is quite a cast. Melissa McCarthy, Bobby Cannavale, Michael Shannon, and Luke Evans all turned in solid performances. I particularly enjoyed the scenes shared by McCarthy and Cannavale. They had fantastic chemistry.The bad can be whittled down to the story and Nicole Kidman's character, Masha. I found Masha to be too icy and hard to like, so the ending was a letdown. Masha wasn't someone you felt sorry for - she was all red flags mixed with crazy.It's shows like these that make me think the actors signed on because it gave them a chance to do challenging scenes alongside really good talent at the expense of a good story.

SummaryHeartless characters, a more theatrical than cinematic dynamic, repetitive and remanned situations, ineffective thriller ingredients and some scenes bordering on the ridiculous characterize this stretched miniseries that shows off some good performances, very good technical lines and the always interesting presence of Nicole Kidman , with a character that only she can sustain.ReviewA group of people attend Tranquillum, an expensive resort in the middle of the Californian hills that offers healing treatments and that is directed by Masha, a guru of Russian origin (Nicole Kidman), in order to overcome her traumas, which we will know sooner than late and that include (as usual) marital crises and breakdowns, creative crises, disappointments, losses and unresolved griefs.Tranquillum's gallery of "nine perfect strangers" and patients consists of a writer (Melissa McCarty), a divorcee (Bobby Cannevale), a gay journalist (Luke Evans), a young millionaire couple (Samara Weaving and Melvin Gregg), a fickle woman (Regina Hall) and a married couple with their teenage daughter (Asher Keddie, Michael Shannon and Grace Van Patten). The main staff of the retreat is made up of Masha and hers two young assistants of hers (Tiffany Boone and Manny Jacinto).Nine Perfect Strangers (9PS) suffers from many problems. In the first place, its soulless characters, whose problems (very common) are described and treated in a way that does not generate interest or empathy for them. More than passing things to them, the characters talk all the time about what happens to them and what happened to them. Although there are some good lines of dialogue, sustained by good performances, this theatrical stamp is not effective in this case. The same happens with the interactions between them, their frictions, approaches and distances, in a dance that becomes repetitive. On the other hand, the links between Masha and hers two of her assistants, and Masha's interventions as a "therapist" are more suggestive. Kidman marks very well the difference between her behavior with them and the "professional" with her patients.Added to this layer of drama is the thriller subplot, characteristic of Liane Moriarty's novels, related to Masha's past, certain strange behaviors of some characters and, above all, with the mystery of what are the hidden purposes of the character of Kidman and his curious treatments and of Tranquillum in general. Not coincidentally, this structure of unknown characters forced to live together in an isolated setting refers to the novels of Agatha Christie.The miniseries (and its conflicts) looks unnecessarily stretched and repetitive and abounds in situations that surround the ridiculous. Instead, the direction, the lighting, the photography and the beauty of the locations are to be highlighted. The actresses and actors do what they can with her soulless characters, surrounding an angelic, mysterious and perhaps Machiavellian Nicole Kidman who, as always, makes the most of her strange Masha. Only she can sustain such a character.

reviews.review_title: Three episodes of this new age dross is three too many IMO
reviews.content: The set up of this show had potential. Nine disparate people with issues thrown together in some weird wellness spa. It set up the intrigue well but didn't progress from that point on. I felt no empathy toward any of the characters. Their emotional travails was of no interest to me. Special mention needs to go out to Nicole Kidman who just came across as weird and creepy to me. Physically she reminded me of a Wraith, the life sucking half bug half human aliens featured in Stargate Atlantis. In my opinion the Wraith exhibited more personality than Kidman's character. Sad as I enjoyed her work at the beginning of her career.

reviews.review_title: Who is this even for, whats its audience?
reviews.content: Jesus, if you thought episode 1 dragged on, episode 2 will seem like an eternity...if i make it to the end of episode 2 i will be amazedIve heard of (and enjoyed the odd) slow burn, but this is glacial, and none of the characters will make you care about them. All are disposable self indulgent types, endemic of our current #AllAboutMe society. Watching Samara Weaving is particularly challenging. She has the look of someone who smelt a fart set permanently as her resting face...i dont know if its surgery or not, but i couldnt deal.Not even McCarthy can save this, and i love her.It seems like a vehicle to show off how amazing Nicole looksOn that it at least achieves...she looks amazeballsOne star.....If you make it beyond 3/4 of episode 2, you are a true masochotist.
My god this is so slow I thought it was in reverse, I mean nothing happens at all. Absolutely rubbish!

A series that starts good and promising, but half-way toward the end (50% in) starts to crumble, showing signs of nothingness and indecisiveness.The acting is good, the storyline comatose and the finale ending, while being artificially nice and "delightful", traces big unhappy craters in your mind, unless watched with the ingested substances shown in the show!

Great Cast...NO Script!Have watched the three available episodes and have yet to figure out what's going on. It's just nine great actors in a remote house with very little drama or story.Here is what the TV exec said.." Hey let's get a stellar cast together in some house and we'll figure it out later."
I'm rating this a 7 purely on the great cast and performances, but not for the drivel the script calls dialogue.Regina Hall is great...Michael Shannon is weird as usual, but good. Melissa always makes me laugh.

reviews.review_title: Stellar cast let down by storyline
reviews.content: Nothing satisfying really happens in this miniseries, even though it starts out very promising, riding on the appeal of big names like Nicole Kidman, Melissa McCarthy, Michael Shannon, and Bobby Cannavale. It happens to premiere mere days right after the jaw-dropping finale of "The White Lotus," and so comparisons and expectations start to be made, being that both shows feature the idyllic backdrop of luxurious resorts. By episode 3, it becomes apparent that this is nowhere anything like "The White Lotus," but perhaps more reminiscent of themes from "Homecoming" where Bobby Cannavale also stars in. At any rate, when that plot line is introduced, it feels very anti-climactic. The subplots don't deliver anything noteworthy either. I just enjoy the banter between Francis and Tony, Michael Shannon's acting range contribution, and of course Nicole Kidman's performance especially at the end. The rest of the "strangers" are rather forgettable. For example, the rich, young couple seems like they are just extra and are not really part of anything. Grace Van Patten, who reminds me of a young Shailene Woodley, clearly has a bright future ahead of her, but the storyline she is given here gets repetitive and a bit boring. Overall, this is worth-watching just to see the all-star cast bicker at each other, but don't expect anything satisfying at the end.
What a complete waste of time it was watching this. Nicole Kidman's fake accent and acting was bad. The characters you find out are pointless and nothing happens. What a disappointment.
Beside the good scenery, basically nothing else, I was patient until episode 6 then I had to fast forward the bs, way too much talking and no action. I won't recommend it.

The story keeps building. Great acting, great engaging story and a wonderful finale. It looks like they're even going to have a season 2. It's a story about a retreat to heal the souls of people who have lost something. It's a little hard to explain, but it's worth your time in the end. Such a great ending.

Sorry, i like Nicole but as a Russian speaker her accent was atrocious. Her "lapochka" was so bad, that i couldn't recognize the word at first. Also, the girl in the end spoke with such a terrible accent.In general, it is plain boring. Not sure what the message was (that psychodelics are cool?) or was it murder mystery? In the end, not recommended, waist of time.

Mistake - I got carried away by the rating , I should have checked the viewers review.Very slow boring and still I am not able to understand what was it all about.The beginning was promising but from episode two I started realising its not going any aware.Dump It.

The original novel was written by an Australian, set in Australia and the series is clearly filmed in Australia. Yet we are supposed to believe it's California, despite the fact it doesn't look anything like California.Then we have Nicole Kidman's strangulation of a Russian accent. For some reason she seems to think it only necessary to attempt it on one sentence out of every three. But we should be grateful for small mercies.As for the series itself, I really don't know why I bothered to give it a chance. I read the book several years ago and thought it was a slow journey to nowhere. Unfortunately, this adaptation is very faithful to the novel.

They say that by the third episode you're hooked on this series. That may be true but after two episodes we found the story to be so boring and the characters so unlikeable that my wife asked me to delete the rest and never waste her time again. I couldn't find any reason to disagree with her.

Wife made me watch this, and even w/all these big names they couldn't even carry this show. Nicole was great in Big Little Lies, but she was she freaky in this.The poor divorced lady who couldn't get over her ex, the family that post their child to suicide. Why would anyone ever want to go through all that pain again.If you're just starting watching this, shut it off now and find something else to kill time.

It should have been darker. Or funnier. Not as deep as it meant to be.This is a story about grief and loss. There is no mystery here, nor twists or thrills. Just a comedy/character driven drama. Some touching moments here and there, also very good actors' perfomances. If you are searching for a comedy/drama series, you will enjoy it. If you are looking for twists and turns and thrills, you will be disappointed. I believe that 6.6/10 is a fair rating, of course this is just my opinion. Above mediocrity but not something special.I don't mind Kidman's accent, she does a great job here, just like every other actor.

reviews.review_title: The best miniseri of a psychological and mystery theme of a long time
reviews.content: If we don't consider continuity, the miniseries "9 Perfect Strangers" is like a long episode of "Alfred Hitchcock Presents". And it has more or less the same suspension and even the same type of cuts. (Although the Hitchcock show cuts flow from a certain carelessness). And making a show in 2021 with these characteristics is due to having Hitchcock-like knowledge, and a deep understanding of a story, and most importantly, understanding and performing a project properly in making a show. But is it enough if we made a series that was as good as a Hitchcock show? Maybe it's enough. But we have to consider what we want to say. And make a picture accordingly.

reviews.review_title: The end fell apart for me
reviews.content: I was so intrigued by the beginning episodes, I read the book because I couldn't wait to get to the end. The book was amazingly satisfying and I couldn't wait to see it on screen.Unfortunately the show went in a different direction. And not for the better. Certain character's professions were completely altered, which was important in the book so the show had to change even more things to adapt. And I'm not sure why. It didn't add anything and went away from the point of the book.I loved the book and movie Jurassic Park. Both are pretty different, but the overall plot and themes are very much the same. 9 perfect strangers is not.I don't like that they share the same name and characters.
We loved it. Keeps you guessing and the ending is excellent. Really a special series. Highly recommend. Don't read any spoilers, just enjoy!!

Nine Perfect Strangers (filmed in Byron Bay) is unlike anything I've ever seen before. Neither Kidman, nor McCarthy dominate. They both play their respective roles so well, it's hard to not like their characters.For crying out loud, I thought I'd never watch a film with McCarthy in it ever again - but this is different.The first three episodes don't reveal much at all... but after that, it all starts to make sense.And the series is not necessarily centred around Kidman/McCarthy - there are many other fine characters, and a lot of humour, fun, weirdness, and micro-dosing :DJust thinking about the show makes me giggle as I type this.It is a limited production series, so it doesn't go on and on senselessly making up new scenarios borrowed from elsewhere. It is very original from my point of view.If you watch it, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

reviews.review_title: Good for insomnia -wasted on great actors
reviews.content: They phoned this in - David E Kelly needs to retire. The goat thing was beyond obvious. May seem daring and edgy to rich Hollywood writers but it was lame and superficial. . . Just like the rest of the script.

Just a catalogue or mosaic of ludicrous figures thrown together in the hope something humorous would happen and then it didn't. Just another 'zaney' would be comedy / drama made for TV easy to miss and no loss if you do.

reviews.review_title: If faking the accent is not realistic - better to drop it
reviews.content: The Russian accent makes me cringe; the story is reasonably mysterious and watchable (at the same time some scenes are overly long and too cheesy to be interesting, but perhaps that was not the aim to begin with).

Undoubtedly the worst television series I have ever been misguided enough to watch all the way through. Clearly written by someone who's fried their brains with drugs and what's everyone else to share the experience.

Sadly, Nicole Kidman has reached a low point in her illustrious career playing some crazy oddball therapist with an atrocious off-key Eastern European accent in this limited series about wealthy folks turning to spa therapy solutions for health and mind improvement. It doesn't help that the series ventures into familiar territories - couple therapies, exotic resort locations, spoiled rich kids, unsolved murders and Melissa McCarthy-meets-and-falls-in-love-with Ben Falcone scenes (again!). If you are looking for holiday escapism to binge in these days of restricted travel, I would recommend HBO'S the White Lotus instead.

I haven't read the book. So I had no idea what to expect.It started well, slow but interesting and kept me watching but then an episode after an episode it got boring and extremly slow. And I lost interest in watching it, I have no idea how it'll end and frankly, I don't care.

reviews.review_title: Read the book or watch the series - not both
reviews.content: Sorry for mini-spoiler, but reading the book spoiled the series for me. Not because they we were the same, but because they were so different. I was turned off by the "Hollywood" of the series. However, Melissa McCarthy absolutely sparkled. All of the actors were brilliant but she really lit up the screen.

reviews.review_title: Who's responsible for ruining this book?
reviews.content: Bloody hell, the book by Liane Moriarty was weirdly unsettling, atmospheric, funny, intriguing and most importantly compelling all the things this series was not. It gave us moments of brilliance, a bit like glimpsing the premise through all the dreary dross on this screen but was mostly just boring. Hard to say why, interesting story, great casting, visually interesting but it just didn't all come together. The parts are more than whole.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful in every way except perhaps Kidnman's face injections
reviews.content: This cast, this setting, this whole vibe of a show is wonderful and I like it better than White Lotus for instance. Just fantastic. Everyone cast get's their fair share of screen time as well and its a wonderful ensemble! The only negative for me personally is that I get distracted by Nicole Kidman's plastic surgery, the implants, the injections, the face lift... I can't even see her real face anymore. She was a beautiful woman and would have aged gracefully, it's a pity. Aside from that, do yourself a favor and watch this show with a partner or friend.

It all boils down to a bunch of strangers who agree to start being lightly drugged until they walk stoned through a wonderful place. Who didn't want to? Good actors, filmed in a beautiful place but... it's a very bland story.

Anything she appears in lately, I'm distracted by her face and what she has done to it. Also she does not seem believable playing a Russian guru, her accent is terrible and seems to overact. Apart from that the rest of the cast are good and it is ok so far with 3 episodes in.

My real score: 5/10. (giving 1 star to balance these 10s).The show is trying to create a feeling of mystery and danger but it just puts you to sleep instead. Every time Nicole makes that "ominous" face - I laugh. She can't play malicious characters, she's born to play victims.And the characters? They just googled "modern personality types" and put them into the story: a washed up writer, internet "star", broken athlete, scared housewife etc. All the character are exaggerated and are unnaturally intense (thou not due to bad acting, but rather a weak script).And plot? A mysterious guru with dodgy methods to make them feel uncomfortable, start crying, find the problem and be healed? Cliché.I 'll have to pass on that. I'll go check that lotus show that some people mentioned instead.

reviews.review_title: I've read the book...you can't judge this after 3 episodes
reviews.content: It's a slow burn with some unexpected twists and turns. You can judge the actors after 3 episodes but the story is just getting started. Hang in there.

This started out good, then plateaus to something less than expected. If you want to watch a somewhat feel good series that offers nothing new and no surprises, just boring ending, this is for you. They had so much to work with and so many directions they could have taken to actually make the series exciting and rock solid, but to many main stars wanted to be the center of attention and always come out looking like the hero at the end. Such a disappointing ending that I stopped and fast forwarded through the last 20 minutes.

I read the book after watching the trailer, so I had images of the actors already in my mind. But they are really perfectly cast. Especially Melissa McCarthy who is spot on. It's almost like the character in the book was written with her in mind to play. Anyway, creative premise with interesting and relatable stories. I wrote this review because I'm so curious about the miserable people who gave it one or two stars. Compared to what exactly? Maybe save that range for actually bad stuff? And lighten up a bit? Loons, the lot of youse...

Great premise, beautiful cinematography, terrific cast. Too bad the plot falls flat towards the end. And the last five minutes are just stupid. Too bad, because it started pretty strong. But then it just lost steam and eventually got ridiculous. To the point that I only gave it six stars and I am being extremely generous.Now the big question is, why do we need to write six hundred characters to comment on imdb? I have read actual film reviews by real film critics that were shorter than that. I think three hundred words would have been just fine, without risking spoiling anything for people who reads it.

I suffered through all of the episodes of this bizarre story hoping so much that the conclusion was going to be so brilliant that I would have been glad that I suffered through this series. Unfortunately, the ending was incredibly disappointing. I gave this review one star for the casting director - the actors did a really good job. Too bad the writing was so bad.
It lack momentum.Cast and acting so so.Filmography to much zoom on torso up.Many scenes needed better direction/script.And getting actors that cost lot less but well directed .

I tried to like it. I wanted to be absorbed within the episodes. I wanted to feel what the characters were feeling. Yet, I didn't like it. I never was absorbed. And, I felt nothing for any of the characters.

reviews.review_title: All those good for nothing tv shows need to stop
reviews.content: I stuck until the end, and I saved my judgment till the end - something I never do - turns out, if it doesn't hook you up soon, it won't.By the end of the show, I'm mostly confused. And I really can't count all the things that are wrong with the show; burn so slow it's going backwards? No real script? Fake Russian accent? Horrible last episode? Predictability? Surprisingly mediocre acting? Deadpan empty dialogues?And I could go on, but it would only mean wasting more time on this empty shell of a production - which you spent more time on that you should too, only having read this review.

I just watched (suffered) through all 6 episodes of White Lotus and I really don't get the comparison of the two shows. This is a good show with an intriguing mystery and interesting and not boring characters who are complicated but like-able. I'm glad that this show is nothing like White Lotus and I can't understand why WL reviews are glowing while 9PS have bad critic reviews when it entertains and draws you in, unlike WL.
It took a min to pick up, but once you connect with the participants it's a very interesting show. Def one of the more emotional stories.

This is really more of a character story drama than anything truly suspenseful. The series also feels a bit stretched out and the actions of some of the characters seems unrealistic. Well-produced but I just didn't find it to be riveting storytelling.

reviews.review_title: 'Strangers' is the right word as 'strange' is what this TV mini series is
reviews.content: We've just finished the first season and rather enjoyed it, but for myself, I'm not really sure what the point... or should I say 'plot' is about?Nine strangers end up at an expensive retreat run by a woman whose odd practices venture into the illegal.Personally, I would have walked out, but the odd thing is none of them do. So for myself, the question this series raises isn't "what is going on?" But, "Why haven't they walked out?"It's a good series and we are looking forward to Season 2.

reviews.review_title: Glad I watched it despite some of the negative reviews
reviews.content: I didn't expect to like this very much. Some of the negative reviews say that it either got more confusing at the end or just was disappointing, and I was afraid it was going to wrap up in an unsatisfying way. It did not, in my opinion! I found myself hooked all the way through, and found the end to be quite interesting.The series makes a lot of statements -- more than appear at first glance. It's the kind of thing I'll probably be thinking about for several days now that I've finished it. Lots of "life" themes that really made me think about my own life and relationships, even though I have literally nothing in common, circumstantially, with any of the characters.All of the actors really brought their A game in my opinion. I love Melissa McCarthy in anything, I won't lie. She didn't disappoint here (she's not only funny -- the lady can act!). Michael Shannon: amazing. Luke Evans: what a textured character he played. I was not familiar with many of the other actors, but I thought they were amazing, from the spa guests to the staff. (I feel like I'm giving a Travelocity review, haha!) I used to detest Nicole Kidman, but she has grown to be one of my favorite actors over the years. Some have criticized her "Russian" accent in this. It won't win any awards, but it was fine. And overall her performance was outstanding.I agree with some reviewers who say this series may seem to glorify behavior that would be truly reprehensible in real life. I would recommend not watching it for "real life" but perhaps seeing if any of the themes hit upon something in your interior life. I would NOT be in favor of any of this stuff unfolding in the real world (I don't want to give spoilers, so I'm avoiding saying what "this" is) but I found myself deeply moved while watching the characters process so many of their issues.I thought it wrapped up just fine. It didn't go in the direction I personally expected it to go, but I didn't feel disappointed. It was neither too formulaic nor too dark (given the material that preceded it!). Queensryche's "Silent Lucidty" as the closing song on the last episode was the perfect touch.If you're going to watch it, I'd say watch it in its entirety and then judge it. It's a complete story, not a series of little stories contained within the episodes. Would definitely recommend!

So did my wife. I turned it off and suggested she go to bed. This show literally put us to sleep. Oh, these people who go to some hokey wellness resort run by a lady with a bad Russian accent and too much botox and act like idiots. That's about all I got out of it so far.

reviews.review_title: Nine perfect stangers must be renamed to Eight boring episodes.
reviews.content: Nothing happened all season, everyone just walks back and forth in this spa and has lengthy dialogues or whines about the same thing from episode to episode. There are so many good actors and they have nothing to play in this advertisement for mushrooms and drugs.

I will start with the only positive thing about this show: the cast was great.I really tried to enjoy this show. I thought it would be good based on the high rating it has, but it's just so blah.I honestly don't know how I even made it to the end. I kept thinking it will get better, it has to. But it was so boring and slow and I had to fast forward a lot of it.A lot of doesn't make sense to me. So these people go voluntarily to this special retreat, and even pay a lot of money. But then the minute they go in they act like they were there against their well and keep wanting to leave, and of course the retreat staff keep trying to convince them to stay. This happens over and over and over again.Masha is supposed to be this amazing unicorn who can help people, but I honestly don't know what's so special about her. Did I just miss her magical abilities somehow? All they do is drug people with psychedelics.This special super secret retreat is microdosing these very disturbed, depressed, unwell people, but only have a total of five people running the place. Depressed and violent people on psychedelics in a place with high cliffs and water all around. Yeah that sounds like a great idea. What could ever go wrong?Delilah (one of the people working in the retreat) looks concerned all the time and questions the doses about 5000 times in every episode. We get it, Delilah is very very very very concerned about the doses.It's not worth the time.

So I don't understand why others gave such low ratings. I'm just a normal person, looking for great: acting, writing, casting, and plot development. Which, as we all know, is hard to find. Characters are three-dimensional right off the bat and the writing makes me want to see where they're gonna end up at the end. In this current "stream-it-all-but-there's-nothing-to-watch" period of time, I was happy to keep hitting "next episode."

3 episodes and nothing happens, just a long long introduction of the nine annoying characters, it could have been done in 20 minutes.Even Nicole Kidman, great actress, is ridicolous in this role, she makes me laugh everytime she comes out with that serious face and funny accent.

I was SO excited for MONTHS to watch this limited series. The book made me laugh and cry from the moment I opened its pages.WHAT A DISAPPOINTMENT. The cast is incredible; zero fault placed upon them UNLESS they also read the novel (shouldn't they have????).I continuously asked myself if I would have felt the same had I not known the entire, eloquent unfolding...
But sh**, I really don't think so.

I thought this was a really good show and Melissa McCarthy and Bobby Cannavale carried a lot of the show as they brought lightheartedness to it. As some people have said in the reviews, if you haven't read the book you won't understand it as such. But it is believable as it's something that (as a European looking in) could happen in America today as it's so bizarre. Definitely worth a watch as there is some funny and cringey moments in it. I also love it when Nicole Kidman plays a sinister character as she always nails it.

Another one that fits her. I like what she does and how she does it. Rest of the cast is well assembled and perform a choral play and as a result the whole thing becomes lovely to see, deep to make you think and a nice recommendation for everyone.

reviews.review_title: Melissa McCarthy needs to Cut the Cord
reviews.content: Nine Perfect Strangers - C- (Disappointing)This has to be the worst show I have ever seen with the amount of talent is attached especially Nicole Kidman, Melissa McCarthy & Michael Shannon. I mean this is just atrocious as everyone is high and talking nonsense for eight hours. That's pretty much the plot.AND Melissa McCarthy need to cut the umbilical cord and lifeline she has given to her husband and her friend Rose Byrne Partner Bobby Cannavale. Every movie or series I watch she is either one of them whether they suit the role or not. The sheer obnoxiousness of her supporting nepotism is just repulsive in every single movie. Her all movies and series are just mediocre at best, forgettable.One of the worst book adaptations I have ever seen.

From the opening theme song "Strange Effect" by Unloved to the well-paced slow-to-strong storytelling approach, "Nine Perfect Strangers" delivered fine entertainment with bold sub-texts.Performances were the heart and soul of this show and without good acting it would have all fallen apart in the first half hour. Scene-stealing as well as filler performances were all on point in this 8-episode series - not sure if there's going to be a season 2.Nicole Kidman's Masha Dmitrichenko was a strange character and role, but appealing and enigmatic regardless. So many amazing A-listers graced this production, and they weren't just there for the popularity vote. They all did good work on this project. Shoutout to Melissa McCarthy's Frances Welty, Luke Evans's Lars Lee, Bobby Cannavale's Tony Hogburn, Samara Weaving's Jessica Chandler, Melvin Gregg's Ben Chandler, Asher Keddie's Heather Marconi, Michael Shannon's Napoleon Marconi, Grace Van Patten's Zoe Marconi, Regina Hall's Carmel Schneider, Manny Jacinto's Yao, and Tiffany Boone's Delilah.It was nice to watch how exceptionally these (and other) characters carried the plotline that lay at the core of "Nine Perfect Strangers" on Amazon Prime Video. Various writers came on board for sundry epis, and each one wrote wonderful scripts that revealed key tidbits only as and when needed - truly kept the mystery and tension going steady.Kudos to Jonathan Levine for being the best captain this ship could possibly have. Through 'nine perfect strangers', he managed to convey a sense of humanity, mystery, thrill, suspense, diversity, and deception, and he did it using elegantly crafted characters and superb timing.Marco Beltrami and Miles Hankins did good work on musical scoring for the entire show. Their work complemented several key scenes and sequences, to say nothing of those calm-and-cool reveals as the show went on.They also interspersed the episodes with some brilliant classic and relatively contemporary songs. My favourites were Peggy Lee "It's A Good Day", Gladys Knight and the Pips "I've Got To Use My Imagination", Gabriels "Loyalty", The Platters "Only You", Annie Lennox "No More I Love Yous", The Avalanches "Running Red Lights", Nicholas Godin "What Makes Me Think About You", Ronnie Milsap "Happy, Happy Birthday Baby", Rihanna "Love On The Brain", Stevie Nicks & Don Henley "Leather And Lace", Dusty Springfield "The Windmills Of Your Mind", Audrey Hepburn "Moon River", and Olivia Newton-John "Xanadu".Yves Bélanger's cinematography was a delicious blend of vivacity and character-centric focus. It was great to see the way he captured each performer in their best light. Outstanding costume, hair and makeup, art direction, and production design as well. They were all subtle and neat, with no tendency to excess. VFX and stunts were good, and 'coloured within the lines'.This series took an ordinary wellness centre - a 'transformation retreat' called Tranquillum in Cabrillo, California - and made it the centre of a not-so-wholesome conspiracy with sinister and mysterious goings-on. "Nine Perfect Strangers" was a bizarre show that broke a few conventions while delivering one of the most entertaining and variegated stories, with psychedelic twists, that I've seen so far in 2021.

reviews.review_title: watch this before The White Lotus
reviews.content: As it turned out, i watched 'the white lotus' and then stumbled upon 'nine perfect strangers'. I can't help thinking that i might have enjoyed it more if i hadn't seen the white lotus, or at least watched this first.Both tv shows deal with strangers huddled together at a hotel or wellness resort.As it is, nine perfect strangers is nowhere near the same league as the white lotus. Really. I'm interested in viewers' thoughts if they watched this 1st and the other 2nd.Shame such talent for such a mediocre story.

reviews.review_title: Only up to EP5, but have been hooked since the start
reviews.content: I am loving this show! Nicole Kidman is ... Wow.. I find her riveting. Each character is so complex yet in a short time so fleshed out. As of the end of EP5 it's obvious there is more here than meets the eye. This is great TV and to find this level of acting and intrigue is a wonderful treat. Highly recommended. Nicole Kidman's production company Blossom Films partnered in bringing this to the screen. She has such a knack for picking projects. This is the second of Moriarty's novels she has had adapted, the first being Big Little Lies. Awesome choices. I read Big Little Lies, now I must read Nine Perfect Strangers!

The fact that many reviewed this series two episodes in is proof positive of the goldfish mentality of many when it comes to entertainment. I have just watched the finale; the show is brilliant.The filmography is beautiful throughout and the acting is superb - Michael Shannon and Melissa McCarthy shine in their roles, covering trauma with depth and feeling.There are a couple of flaws (Kidman's accent and the rushed revelation of Carmel in the end episode) but otherwise I was truly impressed with the show.
A really enjoyable experience...but omg the bad accents!Why not just use the Australian accents?

reviews.review_title: Don't be deceived by the 10 stars reviews!
reviews.content: I can't believe that David Kelley, creator of the absolutely ravishing HBO drama Big Little Lies produced this nonsensical show.It has zero elements of a mystey thriller and well, calling it a drama would be an overstatement too. I just couldn't connect with any character in the first 3 episodes and I am not even remotely psyched to get to know their stories. Also, I am quite certain that the plot is not getting any better in the upcoming episodes, so I am not going to watch any more! The 2 stars in the review are simply out of my sympathy for the talented cast.

I actually liked this show. I wouldn't say it was my favourite, but I thought it was very well done. I have always liked Nicole Kidman...she has definitely changed a lot over the years and strikes me as someone who strives for unattainable perfection. There were times the story was a bit over dramatic and the ending was a bit "white savior"-y but I thought overall it was very entertaining and I liked the happy ending. I think if it were a dark and more open ending like the series "White Lotus" I would not have liked it. I loved White Lotus.... I actually enjoyed that series more than this show but I still thought this was a good watch. The ending suited it, even though it was rather silly. The acting was great and the overall story was pretty good. I think it dragged a little, probably would have done better as a film.

Just a quick thanks to the many helpful, well-written reviews that pointed out how this limited series really doesn't go anywhere. I just finished the third episode and wondered: Am I wasting my time? I gave this show a chance because I like the actors (Kidman, Carnivale, McCarthy, Shannon) and showrunner (Kelly). I was even pleased to see the guy from The Good PLace (Jacinto) onboard in a serious/mysterious role. But then halfway through the third episode I found myself watching the clock--that's a good barometer for me. My favorite shows zoom by: 60 minutes and bam--the credits sneak up on you. Some examples are The Sopranos, The Wire, Deadwood, Homeland, even the White Lotus, which many have already noted the similarities to this series. But White Lotus had some real stakes (death, possible incarceration) along with very funny self discovery. Anyway, thanks again, I won't be wasting any more of my time on this one.

reviews.review_title: A lot to consider here.You ready?!
reviews.content: There has been a lot of talk in non-traditional medical circles, and in the media over, well - over the last 60+ years actually, but much more in the last decade or so. It would be a grave mistake to keep your mind closed and stay tightly opinionated before you've actually reached out and learned something new, something real, true, tested, and analyzed, something completely aside from your what your parents tried to scare you with. They certainly knew nothing different than what our trusted government and our traditional prescription based pharmacology (Big Pharma as we now call it, once we realized what kind of a machine it truly was) and medical professionals told them, and so societies developed a very one-sided, pre-conceived, view of consensus about psychotropic therapy. In fact, many even today dismiss its benefits offhand, assuming it's just another way for Stoners to try and justify their fix, and feed their dependencies without shame. And after all, who hasn't wondered at the irony, the lack of reason shown by an adult with their forth martini in hand lecturing their young about the evils of drugs, hammering at you about Cannibus being a gateway drug to heroin, in denial to this day, most likely, for societal norms and acceptance take a long time to change.
