reviews.review_title: Experience heaven on earth, well, almost
reviews.content: "Tranquilum" is the resort to be in. It offers inner peace, rejuvenation, meditation and rediscovery of self and a promise that the guests, upon completion of their stay, will return with total transformation. It's exclusive, by invitation only, follows a strict selection procedure and is expensive, virtually a once in a lifetime opportunity. Masha (Nicole Kidman) is the spiritual healer here at Tranquilum and its chief architect, a woman of Russian lineage who personally oversees the operations and creates customised experiences for the guests. She is ethereal, shrouded in mystery and authoritative.So when a batch of nine guests from very diverse backgrounds get selected to attend a stay at the resort, the atmosphere is pensive as no one knows what to expect. Most people are there with a purpose to address - broken marriage, death of a loved one, depression, self pity, or dying romance, everyone has a reason, well almost. Their phones are confiscated right at the start to ensure that they don't face distraction and several of them get tested for blood! Strange, why would a resort prescribe blood tests? The guests are about to find out. Over the next few days, they go through a transformation of emotional states, to the discomfort of many, but not without some alignment with their individual objectives. They are also going to find out how Masha is achieving this, to their astonishment, and yet they decide to see this to the completion.Nine Perfect Strangers is a very unique experience, told vividly. With an ensemble cast led by Kidman and including stars like Michael Shannon, Melissa Mccarthy and Luke Evans, watch out for some exceptional performances and an intriguing plot that will keep you engaged through the eight episodes. Nicole Kidman is obviously top of the pick as she essays a role that is steeped in mystery, in total command and yet vulnerable. Michael Shannon and Melissa Mccarthy are fantastic too, and so are Tiffany Boone as Delilah and Grace Van Patten as Zoe Marconi. Don't miss this one directed by Jonathan Levine, and enjoy a beautiful backdrop, lovely music and a laid back discovery session.

I'm now up to episode 5 hoping that the show will get better. I've pretty much given up. Stock characters whose problems are pretty predictable. Except for Melissa McCarthy and Bobby Cannavale I could care less what happens to these annoying people.Also, except for one element, nothing they've done therapeutically is very radical or different. The goat incident was almost funny although I'm not sure that's what they had in mind.Nicole Kidman, whom I usually find intriguing, looks like she's sleepwalking through her role. I just find her character annoying here. Melissa McCarthy gives her character some depth and so does Cannavale. Basically if I was involved in this mess of a therapy resort I would be looking to leave this island by the fastest means possible.

Seems good so far, with great cast, except Kidman.Imagine you go for a spiritual renewal of yourself to a beautiful place, only to find your spiritual guru is a plastic zombie robot. Cos that what Nicole Kidman is today.The rest seems ok, especially other actors - they are great actually.

I keep waiting for it to get better each episode, and it just doesn't. The last 7 minutes of episode 8 just dragged on and on. Do yourself a favour and find something more interesting. Nicole Kidman's acting definitely lacks in this show, and a lot of the other actors are just plain annoying. If I could give it a half star, I would.

reviews.review_title: A big waste of good actors
reviews.content: The whole thing grows nice step by step. The performances are extremely good, some moments are brillant. But the end of all is the most 90s end I have ever seen.
I was slowly dying for 5 episodes than quit watching and came back to life...!Terrible...

reviews.review_title: One big advert for blenders and a stark Botox warning
reviews.content: I read the book when it first came out and really enjoyed it - it was the first one I had read by that author and it made me want to read more of her work (some of which I subsequently enjoyed more than NPS.Anyway, I was really excited about this series, as you are when you have read the source material. But I REALLY didn't enjoy this at all. I was hoping that the last episode would redeem it, but it only made it worse.I am not easily bored but this whole series was incredibly boring. In the end I was only watching it for Melissa McCarthy and Bobby Cannavale because they were the only characters with any chemistry. I didn't actually find Nicole Kidman as awful as other people have said here, but I am glad that I've finished the series so I don't have to watch any more of her. There really needs to be a ban on actors having botox because it just looks awful.Final point - the close up smoothie shots were so over used and very annoying - a bit like watching an advert for a blender over and over again.

It wasn't bad until episode 7 actually, It's pretty bland from episode 7 cuz the story ends so basically and there is no more excitement and curiosity so that makes the whole series bad but it's watchable for the content.

reviews.review_title: I would've given it a ten... if I didn't read the book.
reviews.content: Spoilers from the books... Which might not be spoilers for the show...I watched the first two episodes so far and I was mildly disappointed... it was nothing like the book. I personally loved the book, written by Liane Moriarty. She's incredible. The book was so descriptive and slow paced (which I loved) so when I started the first episode I was mildly let down with how fast paced it was. Obviously you can't include everything from the books but there wasn't many things similar between the two.First big difference is the location. The set is beautiful but it's nothing like how it was pictured in the book. When I read it it was described as an older Victorian building (at least from what I remember) and it's nothing like that. Masha's office was in a tower above the building but here it's just a normal room.Second, nothing is in order and many things were changed. Nobody sees Masha for a big part of the book, that's possibly once again because it's more slow paced but in the show she was introduced to other characters in the first ten minutes?Third, in the book Masha has a heart attack in an office and in the show she's shot...? And who is the girl in Masha's visions? I assume a daughter which would be another difference. Mashas child was only a baby in the books when she's talked about.Fourth, the relationships made so far didn't happen in the books which is fine just not what I expected. Lars and Zoe were never friends. Zoe and Francis were closer. Also Francis doesn't realize Tony is there for what felt like a long time. Also Carmel was not like how she's depicted in the show. She was depressed the whole book and was really quiet.Fifth, I'll stop soon, they took out the part where they can't talk for a few days which was a huge part of the book. Like at least 80 pages. They also didn't do the burying hole thing.Sixth, almost done, Masha was never like... romantic... with Yao until the end when everything goes wrong. Yao is the one with the crush on her.Seventh, last one I think, the room where they all gather is some big dome in the trees but in the book it was in a room in the mansion. It might not seem like to big of a problem but it kinda affects the whole main problem at the end of the books. In the books they are locked in the room and they are made to think that the mansion is burning down... how is that going to happen with it in some dome.Eighth, okay last thing for sure, since it's so fast paced it almost doesn't seem believable with how much power Masha has over the guests... like in the show she's making everyone like cry within the first few minutes of being with them? Like it just doesn't seem believable. That's why I think they should've done what happened in the book and not introduced Masha to the group until they've been broken down a bit. Cause in the book it's like they've already gone through so much and then they meet Masha and they're totally overtaken by her. I don't know if that made sense.Anyways I'll still obviously be watching it and I thought it was pretty enjoyable to watch regardless of it not really following the book and being fast paced. I guess I was just kind of expecting how close big little lies was to the book and how good it was all portrayed. That's why I think if I hadn't read the book before watching I would've definitely given it a ten because I wouldn't have had any expectations for it to follow certain story lines, etc. :)
What an absolute waste of time...Kidman silly accent.. omg where to start.
Wasted opportunity for a good show and wanted time watching 8 episodes waiting for something interesting to develop. It was flat and impossible to connect or have empathy for any of the characters.

They changed way too much stuff from the book. I understand they had to change some things because the book was a lot of internal dialogue, but they went a whole different direction. They added a ton of unnecessary violence and they changed practically every character's motivation and moral system. If you're going to do that, change the name of the series and just say it's loosely based on the book.
Literally. Speechless.Wow.Just, Wow.So bad, it's good!?

Starts of interesting, funny, intriguing, mystery. Then goes weird, silly no real plot or great twist in the story line. Most of the characters are just not likeable at all,Boring depressive .Episode 1-3 8/10 Episode 4 7/10
After episode 4 goes down hill. Only gave it 5 for the first couple of episodes.

It's not an easy watcher, I warn you. The story is bleeding with pain, at times you are drowning in it. It's not entertaining but it is breathtaking. In this smoothie of a film romance, crime, oriental medicine, western therapy and mystery are mixed so strangely and beautifully. Watching it is like going through a maze, the Labyrinth, so often you choose the wrong direction of the plot.Every actor did a great job here, incredible acting, cause their characters go through several transformations, every time it felt like watching real people. Music was mostly good.The story brings some original thoughts on things like drugs and healthcare, forgiveness and hatred, fear and love.

reviews.review_title: 8 hours of my life I'll never get back
reviews.content: My god this was a snore fest. I tried so hard to get into it right to the last episode. Must be one of those arty farty things that I am not capable of understanding. Started off with great expectations but everyone I know gave up.

I really enjoyed this show. I loved the cast and thought it was an interesting premise. Michael Shannon steals the show though, he's actually TOO good! A story about 9 people on a journey to healing with magic mushrooms.

Seemed promising but proved slow with a lacking plot . The end left a feeling of " that was it was all about"
?". Would have been much better if filmed as a 1.5h film than 8 hours of a series.

I loved this series. It has it all; comedy, romance, thrills. Great casting as well! What I loved most about it though is the originality factor. It's hard to find original content these days. Well done.

The show discuss a series of mental health issues with deep care, respect and comprehension. And also portraits a current debate on science and society concerning innovations on mental health treatments. It is a exploration mix of moral dillemas and human deepest fears. I'd recommend to everyone I know.

If you've ever entered the world of psychedelics before, I think this show will resonate with you. Facing the traumas, mistakes and fears, learning to let go. This is the essence of the value of the trip. The story is done well to convey that Masha also has deep traumas which require her to let go. It is well acted and for the indescribable experience that is tripping, I think they did a good job with the message spot on.
Incredibly slow. Uninteresting plot. A shame because the cast is good. Pass.
I was expecting more horror end but happy end was also nice. Great.
This show is nonsense. Don't bother. It's a total waste of time.

I didn't read the book, but I can easily tell that there is a "big reveal" or a "twist" coming, however no matter how good such reveal or twist may be, unfortunately it won't be enough to save the show, 6 episodes so far and it's painfully slow.

Four episodes in and many of the scenes just made me giggle. Whether it was Nicole Kidman and her ridiculous accent or even Michael Shannon who also at times was over the top. At times I liked Melissa McCarthy's acting, but then she reverted to her Mike and Molly days. And do they really have to bring in her husband when it was not part of the book? Even watching Manny Jacinto and his hand gestures brought me right back to The Good Place. I like the book and I don't really care that they didn't follow a lot of it, but the added scenes did nothing to make the miniseries better. Overall just very disappointing because this could've been a good series. I have watched the other episodes sort of but they really don't hold my interest.

The negative reviewers here are brainless twits, who wouldn't know good story telling if it bit them on the bum.Not usually a fan of Australian dramas. Some of the highly publicised ones I've found to be poorly written, overacted and uninteresting BUT "Nine Perfect Strangers" was brilliant!The cast, the script, the story and the location were excellent. Especially the story! I binge watched the series and could not guess the outcome. There are not too many shows of such a high standard around, so when one comes along, I'm usually very surprised and delighted.Congratulations to all involved in the making of this gem ! More please!

I love this show, and how it follows so closely to the book. It's one of those rare adaptions that work really well. Great stories, great acting. I just struggle so much with Nicole Kidman's face! Her and Meg Ryan must see the same Dr, as they both have that Joker look. Her eyes are very expressive, and you can just see what a great actress she could have been, had she not destroyed her upper lip.If you can get past that, this is an excellent series. I can't imagine what they're going to do for the second season, as they covered the entire book, very thoroughly, from start to finish. What could be left?

I loved this show! What a great masterpiece. At first I thought it was going to be slow, but it ended up keeping me entertained and waiting for the next episodes. The acting was great and the idea of these 9 strangers all becoming somewhat family at the end was good. I thought the part where they were all thinking they were going to die was great because it was so true! They all figured out what they really wanted. Loved it!

It really isn't worth the hype. It is about a bunch of people from very different walks of life who are battling their own demons... all they do is take different forms of drugs to hallucinate to try and conquer their struggles. I expected more from the show but they're just in a massive boho house eating vegan food and being fed drugs to try feel normal again...

reviews.review_title: Would be so much better without Kidman
reviews.content: It's quite a fabulous cast that I'm really enjoying, except that every time Masha played by Nicole Kidman is on screen I start checking my phone.Which is a disappointment. Having read the book, I was hoping for magnetic. Instead we get a boring and unexpressive frozen faced bore.Melissa McCarthy and Manny Jacinto are especially great.

It all starts so promising: nice characters played by great actors (some are know, some unknown, some famous) so it kept me glued to the screen. But the further you go, the weider the story evolves. And at the end it is really too much and I do not believe it any more. Plotlines which are too bizar, characters who turn into cliches... no they lost me with every episode a little more. And then nice actors can't keep it together...

reviews.review_title: I read the book, now watching the show
reviews.content:
Some takeaways so far:I like it! I like the changes mostly with the exception of a few that I will outline below. Tbh, I liked the book but also not a lot happened in the book (for those who are complaining that nothing is happening in the series)...the book, though weirdly a page turner, was oddly uneventful in comparison.Changes:
Lars isn't the most gorgeous man alive and he has more depth to his character. I like it.Zack is a fat emo kid - I like it.Lotto winning couple (can't think of their names) are mixed race couple and SHE looks the overdone plastic part she plays in the book to a T but her husband makes zero sense. Not because they are a mixed race couple - he's not even HOT. Like, at all. And she is all like "please bang me again" and it makes no sense lol.Tony is PERFECT I LOVE HIM.So Nicole Kidman isn't an ethereal being whatever it's finedefinitely like that they got rid of the Noble Silence because that would have been a boring showMelissa McCarthy wears a wetsuit in the pool and I cannot decide if it's a cop out or geniusBasically a lot more stuff is happening at the resort and I am into it.

I'm sorry I've stuck with this through 8 episodes. A fiasco. Maybe the worst show I have ever seen. Hoped it would get better but nothing happens. Really, nothing. Carnavale and McCarthy are terrific. Kidman gives the worst performance of her career and she's not helped by the poor script. Maybe the book was decent. If so, they should be ashamed with this lousy production.

Nice cinematography accompanied by snail-like pacing, uninteresting characters and a "mystery" thriller with not even a hint at any mystery 4 episodes in. If you just started the show quit while your ahead because you WILL be disappointed.

I found myself almost ready to sleep a few times. My problem is with the drug use it should have been peyote and this sort of thing was well covered on Grace and Frankie in one episode (take a trip because of the other person). Overall most of the time you couldn't tell where the story was going. It would have been stronger to have each person more integral to each other, in one past moment that felt individual to each and initially unrelated and then to eventually understand their connection of that moment at the last episode. I watched the whole first season in one sitting. Overall I don't think I will watch it again as I didn't find anything deep enough, twisted or tricky enough to relate to or have to explore again later. The best shows you can watch again and again whether it be back to back or a few months apart, like a great song. This show I saw to watch it once and then talk to others but never go back to watch again.

What a marvelous, weird, touching, psychological and pshycedellic show. Wow!This is not quick entertainment. This is like reading a sorta slow but brilliant book.It will catch you with it's mystery, move you with the characters traumas (you should be able to mirror yourself in some of the issues they have) and it will just leave you baffled. Maybe it will even help you heal yourself! You almost feel like you are a participating "patient".I totally loved it! Absolutely quality tv!!!!The shots are beautiful, it is cut brilliantly, and it is very well made. The actors are phenomenal!Yes, Nicole is a bit eerie to behold.. but she plays the character perfectly!!!!!! And I think she looks fine for her age, depsite having botox done etc. It shouldn't take away for how amazing her acting is in this.The show is even funny at times.Would love to see more shows like this! Wow!

Most people dread watching the last episode bec' they don't want something to be over...I was the exact opposite. I regretted the previous episodes that I had sat thru' over the past few wks...I didn't think this finale would make any difference. Without spoiling it, it did. It was memorable & poignant for me to watch. I lost someone to suicide like the teacher & his Family. It was beautifully concluded & some of the characters who I had no interest in...suddenly mattered more. Hang in there for last 20 or 30 mins. You made me realize I was wrong about this show & I welcome being enlightened & surprised.

I just finished the show and i can say that it was a great great great.I like the idea of connecting with nature and people thorough psychedelics, so this show will offer you many aspects of the mushrooms world.The end twist wasn't the best one, but overall a great idea that can keeps you intrigued.

While the premise of the show is quite alright, the show very quickly demonstrates how aimless it is from the second episode on. The characters' stories are interesting enough, but the way their problems get resolved is not and the fact that Tranquillum is supposedly some prestigious retreat becomes laughable when you realize how inept the characters running it are.The actors involved are talented enough but the way they behave or react to what's going on makes very little logical sense and it feels as though each character was written by a writer who hadn't bothered to communicate with his teammates and who was too lazy to read the summary of what the characters and story is supposed to be.

reviews.review_title: Even good actors can't overcome a lame story and terrible direction
reviews.content: I was hoping that the final episode would salvage this weak effort, but instead it just added insult to injury. I cringed at the ridiculous final half hour. Shame on a fine actor like Michael Shannon for adding this trash to his otherwise brilliant career. Regina Hall was unbearable.

I've read the reviews saying to stick with it, but I just can't get through it. I must have stopped and started again 6 times. I'm partway through episode 4. It's just awful. I think people who have read the book only like it because they read the book.

I've read the book. The series is decent. I probably would have found it more entertaining had I not read the book. So much is unlike the book. I won't provide spoilers. In 6 episodes they could have made it more similar to the book. Or maybe the series is better with the changes. Undecided.
Waste of valuable time. No storyline just passing time, worst series ever I had watch.Pathetic cinematography climax is filthy.Just go and watch another movies.
Interesting show, with interesting characters. Good entertainment. Probably won't watch it again. The title sequence is pretty cool, a brief idea of what a mushroom trip feels like.

reviews.review_title: Under rated show that deserves more attention.
reviews.content: Probably worth to block out a weekend and binge watch this show if you can. The theme unravels slowly the plot and the series are in line with the psychedelics used by the characters; what others see as weakness is actually the strength. The last 2 minute Hollywood ending was un-necessary and cheapens the message and artistry of the show to please the audience. It is interesting to see Mellissa Mc. In a semidramatic role she made it work.

It's an easy watch series with subtle comedy drama and mystery. Great scenery and visuals easy to watch. It takes you on relaxing journey at the beginning. There's plenty of character build ups while the plot thickens. I loved it. It was a relaxing few hours for me.
The only TV show I watch. Finally something serious and more educational. It's deep and beautifully made.

Watching from Australia via Amazon Prime, we will get the final episode tonight. My thoughts so far:LOVE Francis and TonyWhy is Nicole Kidman Russian though? Makes absolute zero sense. Totally randomI really dislike Samara Weaving's character. She has no depth or personality. Now that I am writing this I am wondering what the point is of her and her husband in this show? They are pointless with no story line and really boring characters. Are they just there to be the token pretty people?Not a fan of Carmel, but I think this was a casting stuff up. I much prefer Regina Hall as a comedic actress. I am hoping her character will get better and add to the storyline. Also....why the freaky eye? To make her look scarier/crazier?Overall the show drags on a bit, feel like we still don't know too much about anything really but I'm still hooked. I'm looking forward to future episodes that will hopefully tie the whole thing together. Love the Australia setting and seeing lots of Aussie actors.

All I have to say is that it is an awesome series and I will definitely be reading the book as well after this. It's crazy how the story keep morphing. Never knew how intense and exciting a retreat for wackos could be.Don't wanna give spoilers but if it isn't your thing, move along, no need to leave negative comments like your life depended on this movie being exactly the way you like it.

Amazing acting, atmosphere and soundtrack - bad reviews most likely from those who watched half an episode and have a low attention span / only watch action packed series. Really recommend for those that are interested in psychology!

reviews.review_title: Overly long with questionable treatment of suicide
reviews.content: If you can last the full 8 episodes then you could be a candidate for the next season's therapy intake or you just have an unwavering drive of commitment to see it through.Easy to see the main characters were most likely finalised from a marketing data survey of those likely to be attracted to the story lines, yet where were any young males, the very people who are the real suicide perpetrators? They may have benefited if they ever watched it past the first episode. Call me cynical but when suicide as a theme treated in this way, it's no wonder society sees rates increasing as superficial myths are perpetuated by lack of inconvenient truths. At the very least, the sister character should have been a twin brother and that may have helped drive a greater understanding for young male viewers but boys, as opposed to girls, wouldn't have been a bigger driver of subscriptions.Two jarring elements besides the entire drip-fed story lines - the inappropriate use of Xanadu music and the nerve wracking iPhone alarm sound. Yes, if you didn't need therapy after watching the entire 8 shows, then you sure did realise after Xanadu and being woken up for close to 10 minutes by the loud, jarring iPhone alarm, perhaps placed to wake up those put to sleep or dead from reaching the end of the Season 1, that the writers and those participating in this bad endeavour were in need of something far better in their lives. I know I should have had something better after staying to the end.

I m still not done watching the first season but I just had to stop episode 5 and write a review.I read so many lukewarm or mediocre reviews about this seriee that I almost did not wach it.Boy am I glad that I started it. This is one of the most intriguing series of the year. The story is a good combination of bittersweet comedy, mustery, drama and even a bit thrillerish at times.The cast! My God the cast is spectacular! Nicole Kidman,Melissa McCarthy, Bobby Canavale, Luke Evans, Regina Hall, all being extraordinary good in my opinion. I m thrilled about the last 4 episodes and am sure they wont be a letdown.

I've only watched the first two episodes so far, but I find this to be a well scripted and well acted drama, The characters are larger than life, but not so much so that you can't relate to their struggles to understand the process of life around them. Nicole Kidman's performance is especially strong and is a pleasure to experience. It's rare to find such an original and enthralling series that tackles seemingly mundane issues. I am looking forward to watching the remainder of the sreies and hope it will not disappoint.If in doubt give this a go, hopefully you will gain as much from it as I have.
Just watch the last episode and you would save several hours of your life. I suppose writers and actors were not paid enough so decided to take revenge with sloppy writing and soulless acting.

Uhm, where to begin. I am not really sure how I feel about this show.I started primarily because it has - in my opinion - a great cast and to be honest: they delivered. McCarthy in a role we've hardly (if ever) seen her and Cannavale back in a role he porteits best: a little bit messed up. I didn't understand why the accent of Kidman's character was needed. I felt it distracted from her performance and even the character itself. The shows first (and only) season did not reveil clearly enough why she's here and where she's been. Unfortunately, this is true for all characters. A lot of time is lost on unimportant storytelling. The only story being really told is that of the Naploen, Heather and Zoe and it's full of amazing shot and acted scenes. The rest of the character's stories lacked depth and persuasion which is sad because I feel like this show could have been great.Maybe read the book instead?

reviews.review_title: Strong cast, well built characters, good story
reviews.content: The cast and the characters built in this show were really strong. I didn't always love Regina Hall's character, but that was more down to the writing and I would argue that this is Melissa McCarthy's best performance ever. She was the right amount of funny and real without having to rely on cheap self-deprecating humor.The story purposefully gets a little more weird and loose as it goes on and while I do think the writing was much stronger in the first half of the episodes the whole arch was definitely great and intense at times.
Amazing cast! Nicole Kidman should when an award for this. Great story line, a few surprises and deep messages. Very entertaining. Truly wish there was another season.

reviews.review_title: Write About What You Know - SPOILERS!
reviews.content: SPOILERS WARNING!Just because you read a few Strassman or Hoffman books and heard about a few studies does NOT mean you understand psychedelics effects or potential.This show is kind of fun in a fluffy popcorn and candy way but for those who have spent some time on the Other Side frankly it is kind of dumb.Pseudo diverse people most of whom are ridic wealthy without earning it go to a wellness retreat and soon learn they are being microdosed. Will this heal them or fracture them more? Do we really care?

A filthy rich people with problems get together for new age help, and I'm not sure whether you're supposed to believe the resolutions are possible or not. Either way, it's a real effort to sit through 8 episodes of this tedious crap. I can't help feeling a lot of the scenes had to be redone because the actors couldn't keep a straight face. There are much better ways to waste 8 hours of your life.

Love This Show Very Much.The cast is playing very good, script is written perfect and director did a very good job. Love the concept behind the show.Definitely one of the good ones in this past years.

That sums up this show in one word. I don't mind a slow burn if you know something is coming. This show was just boring. I don't care about any of the characters. They are mostly some level of obnoxious. Nicole Kidman's accent is so bad it's distracting. There is not really a story. Some of the acting was good, that is why I gave it a 4 not a 1 or 2. This show lost me after episode 3. I couldn't even finish it out of sheer boredom. I doubt anything that could come after this point would be worth it.
Wonderful landscapes, mystery, sexiness and witty moments all in one.Manny Jacinto, Nicole Kidman Melissa McCarthy and Michael Shannon are splendid.
The first episode peaked my interest. The second episode, interest waning. Had to force myself through the third. This is one of the most asinine stories I've had the displeasure to waste my time on.

Fist off, no one is having withdrawals from microdosing and secondly, microdosing is not going to get you off oxycodone or prevent the horrific withdrawals and these are just two things horribly wrong with this garbage.
I am really enjoying this show. The acting is top notch in my opinion. Especially Regina King and Samara Weaving. And when did Jason from The Good Place get so hot? Not a regrettable watch.

reviews.review_title: If your looking for another winner like Big Little Lies then back away...
reviews.content: So I'm a huge fan of the show Big Little Lies, recently read the book and was amazed. So I was excited to see another David E Kelly produced show based on another Liane Moriarty book.I read the book right before starting to watch this series and for those who reviewed after the first episodes were right it did stick close to the book but after that everything goes a off kilter. The acting is great I didn't dislike Nicole Kidman like many other reviewers did. The writing however I found a little ridiculous. Would have been far more enjoyable if it kept closer to the book.

Based on Liane Moriarty's novel of the same name, Nine Perfect Strangers is an ensemble treat for sore eyes. But does it live up to the hype of it's stellar cast & Moriarty's Big Little Lies' follow-up adaptation? Sadly, it is an epic disappointment!Nine Perfect Strangers is the story of nine strangers who come for a ten day retreat at Tranquillum House. The house is run by Masha, a mysterious foreign woman. With time, they discover many secrets about the resort, the way it functions and some unsavoury truths about the guests and Masha herself.Nine Perfect Strangers could not have been any better. With a cast that boasts of Nicole Kidman, Melissa McCarthy, Michael Shannon, Luke Evans, Samara Weaving, Regina Hall, Bobby Cannavale, Manny Jacinto among others; the expectations were sky high! But the only thing or one "high" here is the cast. Kidman's Masha has a weird accent, Shannon seems out of place as the over enthusiastic father, Weaving is miscast as the beauty obsessed Jessica. McCarthy & Cannavale are the only ones who are bearable.Nine Perfect Strangers could have been so much better given the tepid source material. They could have improved it a lot given the immensely talented cast. Sadly, the creators manage to make it much worse than the book!Tranquillum House is our second mysterious (fictional) resort of 2021. But do steer clear!
World needs more stories like this. Absolutely loved it.

I really liked Nicole Kidman and Melissa McCarthy who were the producers of this miniseries. It started off pretty interesting and keeps you guessing which way it's going. Whether it's a drama or thriller. I was super disappointed with the ending. I felt that somethings were not explained and leaves you guessing. I also felt like it was rushed and I was expecting more of a surprise ending but it definitely fell flat. Still it was watchable because there's not much on but, don't expect much. I also don't know why Nicole Kidman had to have a Russian accent because it was kind of annoying and I wish she would stop kidding cosmetic surgery . Overall, it's worth a watch but don't expect much.
First episode in and it's great so far. Would recommend!

Amazing cast. I wasn't convinced on the plot at first, by the end of the 3rd episode I was hooked. I, myself have been interested in trying Micro Dosing. I have tried mushrooms a couple times and acid once... I would 100% be down for a wellness facility that practices micro dosing.
This is a great series. It shows the power of healing through unconventional therapy. Psychedelics and is really emotionally charged. I really enjoyed it!!

reviews.review_title: Slow to start, but holds attention
reviews.content: I don't really understand the negativity the show is getting. Tons of top tier series started out as slow burners. Is Kidman's accent and expressions forced? Absolutely. But that's truly the only con I can say so far. It doesn't divulge much to begin with, and that's okay, because the confusion brings you back to try and figure out what's truly going on. It's ominous, and strange. It's shot well with beautiful scenery. The characters are typical, but I still found myself interested in learning more about each one. There's a reason why most therapy, with or without psychedelic microdosing, is not carried out like this, as is there surely a reason why most set-ups like this in fiction devolve into nightmare cult scenarios. Whether those two reasons are precisely the same, the nightmare's ultimate failure to appear here (despite a little flirting with it to tease us) is, on paper at least, wildly implausible.Instead we get a fantasy of a total, highly accelerated, deep dive psychotherapy capable, in one week, of curing a murderous psychotic and totally repairing the family of a recent teen suicide. To achieve these and other miracles, the process here must dispense with the simple old therapist's tools of a long training, a quiet room, patience and close attention in favour of a luxury spa in a verdant paradise, wildly elaborate mind games, fasting, sweat lodges, hot springs, skinny dipping, primal screaming, violent acting out and, in particular, escalatingly drugged smoothies.(Wait, didn't we try all this in the '60s and find it bogus?!)It shouldn't work even in fiction any more than it probably would in real life, but somehow for me it did. I'm not totally sure why, but I think the point well made may simply be about how difficult it is to identify, share and finally unpick the tangles of knots in our own psyches and how that can certainly make such extreme measures feel desirable. Some of the more plausible group therapy scenes here reminded me a little of the old '60s films of Fritz Perls's gestalt therapy groups (several available free on YouTube), which appear similarly quick at getting to remarkable depths. I've often wondered watching those films whether there was a way to make that kind of material work in fiction. Nine Perfect Strangers sort of does it, though I'd like to see it handled much more austerely, without what one of the characters here calls the Instagram moments, which are perpetual (even if they're not allowed to share them on Instagram).It is, in the end, good to talk, good to engage with others and good to get past the resistances that prevent us from doing that vulnerably, humanely and honestly, and I liked this for the way it shows that. The drugs part is pure BS though, just another version of how narcotics both legal and illegal are so often resorted to as a shortcut. I know psychedelic microdosing is currently developing a lot of therapeutic caché and there may be something to that. I haven't looked into it yet, but I'll lay ten to one it's not being done like this, with the microdoses switching abruptly to macrodoses and delivering realistic hallucinations of dead loved ones.Meanwhile, what I do know of therapy can achieve strongly beneficial effects in terms of insight, relief and general happiness with no drugs at all. Gestalt is good (check out Perls's, Hefferline and Goodman's book 'Gestalt Psychotherapy'), but I think Transactional Analysis is even better (as laid out in Eric Berne's books) and have also got an invaluable address to anxiety from Hilary Jacob Hendel's book on a therapy called AEDP, 'It's Not Always Depression.'And here's the big problem with NPS's therapy if taken even half literally (and, yes, I realise I may be overthinking it): what you get from those books, what they understand, is that real therapy is madly tricky. It's not, as per the fantasy here, simply about 'healing' or crying it out or hugging it out or sharing our deepest hurts. Berne, in 'Games People Play' even identifies this kind of thing, in therapy groups, as a game, seductive but ineffective. He calls it 'hothouse' because it involves people bringing out their supposedly deepest wounds like rare orchids for everyone else to marvel at and coo over.Is that what I've been doing watching this show? I half suspect so. On the other hand, I read some of the more negative reviewers here dismissing it all as 'pointless' and similar and wonder if some of them aren't as closed into their shells as many of the characters here were very plausibly shown to be at the start.

reviews.review_title: Edge of the seat show, Great Social Commentary
reviews.content: Nine seemingly well off participants walk into a retreat, and leave bonded for life. The tragedies that have befallen each individual reveal to the viewer (or reader, if you've also read the accompanying novel) the lack of care that trauma has in regards to societal class. Marta, an immigrant from eastern Europe, suffers unimaginable pain from the loss of her daughter. The Marconi family, a middle class family of three who are also suffering from the loss of a family member -- the son, Zach, who committed suicide. Every character has their story, and each is filled with grief, guilt, and a questioning of selfhood. There is a dramatic deviance from the people you see at the beginning of the show, who all present as rich, well taken care of characters who only wanted a weekend away. In reality, each person is dealing with massive internal damage, and were hand picked by Marta to live out that damage in hopes of repair. This show gives a unique view into mental and physical health, rejecting the frequently misunderstood prerogative that stability comes with wealth. No matter the class status of the individual, each and every one of them must come to terms with their inner demons. Although some of the characters seem higher class than others, like Lars or Masha, they are still able to experience the same amount of emotion as any of the other characters. As seen in the show, even though Masha seems so healthy and peaceful, her grief is even more extensive than that of the Marconi family, who is shown publicly falling apart beginning at their first scene. The notions of cultural stratification or status markers are all fabricated external validation directed at others. Internally, humans handle issues and emotional fatigue with similar psychological and physical responses. While the extent of the response may vary, internally we all understand in our own way fatigue, anxiety, grief, and burnout, among others. Pop culture is a reflection of our society's preoccupation with social stature, but the separation that our social standings create alter our perception of true human values and the inner self. The true self is vastly underrepresented both in the media and in daily interactions. Nine Perfect Strangers brings this idea into light, showing the viewer that age, gender, and social status do not create the barriers society tells us that they do.

The first six episodes, really solid, if questionable focus at times. The atmosphere is eerie. The camera shots are confusing. The characters all have secrets.What's up with Masha's mysterious past? Who really was the cause of the son's suicide? What's the deal with Carmel and Lars? Will Frances and Tony make it work? What's Masha's real game with these people's lives?Until we get to the final episode where it's revealed...
Masha really was just a therapist who wanted to help her clients. And she probably broke the law a hundred times yet gets off scot-free. And everybody had a neat happy ending, as a result of a fake near-death experience given to them by the Tranquillium staff. Two of the main characters even went to work at Tranquillium somehow, while the murderous villain actually became a therapist and became in charge of administering therapy to others very shortly after?! Meanwhile, Delilah, the staff member who had been imprisoned at her workplace and had to drive through a fence to get out, happily reunited with her husband who collaborated in her imprisonment?!I felt that the focus on the Marconi family throughout at the expense of all the other characters was somewhat gratuitous and overblown. The trauma was interesting and well-acted, but it detracted from the storylines of some of the rest of the group, and consistently treating the family as a single unit devalued the individual members, especially given that they were all adults.On the positive side, all characters were well-acted and the cinematrography and stylization was excellent. The consistent eerie tone and suspicion-inducing soundtrack however turned out to be inappropriate for the ultimate tone of the series - a successful therapy session. The direction seemed instead to be hinting at a wider mystery - societal apocalypse, a mad science subplot etc. And that it was truly in the SF genre rather than essentially a simple surface level family/bereavement drama with additional drug themes.

I really can't comprehend the negative reviews. (I've never even heard of the book, much less read it. So I'm firmly not in the "fans of the book" camp.). And it's about a self-proclaimed wellness guru not a therapist or licensed medical professional ... so I really don't get the folks screaming about licenses and professional standards.Is it weird? Yes. Intentionally so.Is Masha (Nicole Kidman) weird/ethereal/off? Yes. Intentionally so.Among other things, this show is about broken people who are not being helped by "normal" medicine (Tony) or normal therapy (Napoleon/Heather/Zoe and Chantal) and others who have been ground down by societal/cultural norms (Frances, Jessica/Ben, Lars, Tony). Masha too. So they are search for something - anything - that'll help them escape the hell of their day to day. Kasha's "protocols" are unconventional but - ultimately- effective. (And the treatment of suicide is spot on and very affecting.).It's beautifully written, beautifully acted (Melissa McCarthy, Bobby Canavalle, and Michael Shannon, in particular), and beautifully shot.

This series is a must. Each of the people are coming in with their own life tragedies, and have to work through their emotional issues at this retreat with Masha (Nicole Kidman) at the helm. From death to break-ups to drug addiction, each of these none people were somehow "chosen" by Masha (we don't know why), and there is some kind of sinister shennigans going on (it appears), by Masha who has a week to heal these people and renew their lives. But something isn't right, and it may be that Masha (who had died and come back to life from a gun shot wound) may be the one with the most emotional issues. Either way, the acting is good, and the issues are real. The interplay between the characters makes you feel as if you are there with them. This series has a lot of potential and pulls you in. Luke Evans plays the bad boy with some kind of secret. Bobby Cannavele is an underrated great actor -- some of his scenes will be award worthy. Nine Perfect Strangers is a limited television series that was released on Hulu in 2020. Based on the novel of the same name by Liane Moriarty, the show follows nine strangers who come together at a luxurious health resort in the hopes of improving their lives.The show is led by an impressive cast, including Nicole Kidman, Melissa McCarthy, Luke Evans, and Michael Shannon. Kidman plays Masha, the owner of the resort, who claims to have developed a revolutionary new method for improving people's lives. McCarthy plays Francis, a woman struggling with obesity and low self-esteem, while Evans plays Ben, a charming and successful writer who is struggling with writer's block. Shannon plays Tony, a gruff and skeptical man who is at the resort to support his wife, who is struggling with addiction.The other characters at the resort include Lars, a wealthy businessman who is struggling with a midlife crisis; Zoe, a young woman who is recovering from an eating disorder; Napoleon, a former soldier with PTSD; and Yvette, a woman who is dealing with the recent loss of her husband. Each of these characters has their own personal struggles and motivations for being at the resort, and as the show progresses, we see them all begin to confront and work through their issues.The show does an excellent job of exploring the complex and often conflicting emotions that each of the characters are dealing with. Through the use of flashbacks, we see glimpses of each character's past and the events that have led them to the resort. We also see the dynamic between the characters change and evolve as they begin to open up to one another and form unlikely friendships.One of the most compelling aspects of the show is the way it handles the issue of mental health. Each of the characters is struggling with some form of mental illness or emotional issue, and the show does an excellent job of depicting the challenges and stigma that often come with these issues. It also highlights the importance of seeking help and the transformative power of therapy and self-care.Another interesting aspect of the show is the way it explores the concept of wellness and the lengths people will go to in order to improve their lives. Masha's methods at the resort are unorthodox and often border on the extreme, and we see the characters struggle with whether or not to trust her and follow her teachings. The show does a good job of raising questions about the true nature of happiness and the extent to which we are willing to go to achieve it.Overall, Nine Perfect Strangers is a thought-provoking and emotionally charged television series that tackles important issues such as mental health and the pursuit of happiness. The strong performances from the cast and the well-written characters make it a must-watch for anyone interested in these themes.
